awd_titl_txt: PRIMES, MathROOTS, and CrowdMath: Expanding Opportunities for High School Students
awd_abstract_narration:
PRIMES is a free, year-long after-school research and enrichment program for high school students, based at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. It includes three main sections: MIT PRIMES offers research projects in math and computer science to students from Greater Boston; PRIMES-USA is a national math research program for high school juniors; and PRIMES Circle is a math enrichment section for urban public high school students from the Boston area. In collaboration with MIT Admissions, PRIMES also runs MathROOTS, a free two-week math enrichment residential summer program for high-potential high school students from underrepresented backgrounds or underserved communities. PRIMES has developed an innovative approach, based on the combination of learning and research, which allows high school students to learn advanced areas of math and science and to participate in cutting-edge research within a year-long timeframe. Projects are formulated by university faculty and mentored by graduate students and postdoctoral scholars. Every year, more than 90 students participate in PRIMES. They present their projects at an annual conference at MIT, open to the public; they write research and expository papers, posted online for free access; and they submit original research for publication in academic journals. PRIMES gives talented high school students  a unique opportunity to experience the joy and beauty of mathematical research, inspires them to pursue careers in the mathematical sciences, and helps diversify the mathematical community by providing additional opportunities for promising young women and underrepresented groups. 

In this project, PRIMES students will work on research projects on a variety of pure and applied mathematical topics, which include Branching types of rational functions; Statistics and combinatorics of curves on surfaces; Jacobians of finite graphs; Quasiinvariants; Representations of rational Cherednik algebras in positive characteristic; Folding random walks; Multi-crossing number for knots; Traffic modeling, multi-phase flow, and autonomous cars; Superalgebra in characteristic 2; Sets of permutations invariant under valley-hopping; and Pattern replacement equivalences of permutations. Reading groups will study texts on abstract algebra, the probabilistic method, Abel's Theorem, representation theory, analytic number theory, and cryptography. Enrichment topics will include knot theory, probability, game theory, graph theory, and combinatorics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
PRIMES is a free mathematical research and enrichment program for high school students, created in the MIT Mathematics Department in October 2010. It includes several sections: MIT PRIMES offers year-long research projects and guided reading in mathematics, computer science, and computational biology to students from Greater Boston; PRIMES-USA is a national math research program for high school juniors and sophomores; PRIMES Circle is a math enrichment section for urban public high school students from the Boston area; MathROOTS is a two-week math enrichment residential summer program for high-potential high school students from underrepresented minority groups; and CrowdMath is a massive online collaborative year-long research project open to all high school and college students around the world.

PRIMES gives talented high school students a unique opportunity to experience the joy and beauty of mathematical research, inspires them to pursue careers in the mathematical sciences, and helps diversify the pool of students interested in mathematics by providing opportunities for young women and underrepresented groups.

In 2019-2022, 337 high school students participated in mathematical research and reading under the guidance of their academic mentors. They have authored 84 research papers, 21 of which have already been published in academic journals, gave presentations at 9 conferences, and won more than 100 awards at national and international science competitions. Among the participants, 34% were female and non-binary, and 22% - students of color. 

PRIMES has developed an innovative approach, based on the combination of learning and research, which allows high school students to learn advanced areas of math and science and to participate in cutting-edge research in a short period of time. Projects are formulated by university faculty and mentored by graduate students and postdoctoral scholars. MIT PRIMES has provided an innovative, year-long model for guiding high school student research. PRIMES-USA has developed techniques for remote mentoring via video teleconferencing. PRIMES Circle has developed an engaging math enrichment curriculum for young women and underrepresented groups. MathROOTS has developed an innovative curriculum of creating problem-solving and a set of social activities for integrating students of color into campus life. CrowdMath has adapted the Polymath model for high school research mentoring in the open online forum format.

PRIMES has developed a set of guidelines for formulating successful mathematical projects for high school research:
1. Accessible beginning. The initial steps must be simple to get started.
2. Flexibility. It is useful to think about several related questions, switching from one to another if stuck, and to tweak the questions if they are too hard or insufficiently interesting.
3. Computer (experimental) component. A possibility of computer-assisted exploration aimed at finding patterns and making conjectures is very useful. In this case, students, who often have strong programming skills, can contribute to the project early, even when they don’t yet have a working knowledge of the theoretical tools. It is also easier to learn new mathematical concepts, e.g., those from algebra and representation theory, through a hands-on experience with a computer algebra system.
4. Adviser involvement. It is important to have an opportunity to consult with a research mathematician other than the mentor – usually the professor or researcher who suggested the project.
5. Big picture/motivation. It is important to connect, at least at the level of ideas, to a wider context and to other people’s work.
6. Learning component. The project should encourage the student to study advanced mathematics on a regular basis.
7. Doability. It should be reasonable to expect that a good student would obtain some new results within several months and produce publishable results in one year.
8. Relation to the mentor’s research program or area.

The results of PRIMES research have been widely disseminated at conferences, posted online for free access, and submitted to academic journals for publication.

PRIMES has explored various formats of research and enrichments activities, such as individual and group research projects, directed reading group, distance mentoring over telecommunication channels, studying advanced topics in a game-like setting, writing of research and expository papers, and conference presentations. The experience of running the PRIMES program has been summed up in an article by PI Pavel Etingof and two members of PRIMES staff, Slava Gerovitch and Tanya Khovanova, Mathematical Research in High School: The PRIMES Experience, published in The Notices of the American Mathematical Society 62 (2015). PRIMES has established partnerships with a number of other universities. The dissemination of the PRIMES experience should encourage creation of similar programs at other academic institutions.
